title: Moonlight
critic: Ultimately, Moonlight is cinema that's vital and profound. If there is any way humanly possible to put this film in front of your eyeballs, you owe it to yourself to do so. This movie is why movies exist.
public: A masterpiece that makes you feel for the character. The separation into three parts was a great idea, and it conveys its message. It shows Chirons development in a way that makes you feel for him, hard. It shows you the worst moments, and the outcome in the end, wraps it all up perfectly, he truly finds himself

critic: MOONLIGHT is not a portrait painted in broad brushstrokes, but a tapestry - any one strand can be admired for its own technique and qualities, but standing back to observe the whole is where the power lies.
public: A young gay boy tries to come to terms with himself against a backdrop of bullying and intolerance. Beautifully shot and well acted throughout, but also incredibly slow and ponderous which won’t be to everyone’s taste. I thought the young kid and the teenage actor both played the character really well, but I was less convinced by the adult version for some reason. The emotions are strong in this film and you really care about the characters. A well made film, but from an entertainment point of view it’s not one I’d want to watch again and again.

critic: Barry Jenkins' screenplay is beautiful in its simplicity, relying just as much on its stars' exceptional abilities to move the story along during moments of silence.
public: This film is utterly flawless. A24 in my opinion is a breeding-ground for near-perfect films, and this is one of the few that have actually turned out perfect. Everything from the screenplay, casting, acting, cinematography, editing, I was simply taken by all of it. There are few films that can hypnotize me and and keep me in its grasp from beginning to end, and this is one of those films. It is so subtle, and yet so powerful. It's not a movie that lets its actors goes over-the-top with emotion, but rather the opposite, keeping it bottled up and that makes it all-the-more realistic. As I mentioned, each performance given in this movie is impeccable. So many moments gave me chills and moved me to my core. I've never been so invested in a character-study movie before, and I find myself rewatching it over and over again, each time it getting better and better, picking up more slight details along the way. Easily one of the best movies of the 2010's, and of the best character-piece movies of the 21st century thus far, in my opinion

critic: Moonlight has tremendous value both as unflinching dissection of a long-standing problem in the community and for the depiction of a kid with few choices who is unable to rise above the obstacles in his path.
public: Overhyped and forced , this film could have used some more dialogue and a louder audio track for that dialogue. Minimalism is a great artistic tool, it just doesn't work with this script. And with the best scene being when Little smashes a chair over the head of one of his bullies, that says alot for a movie that covers so many important topics - where the most entertaining scene can be found on a WWE pay-per view.

critic: The film is largely about the physical and emotional violence that's done to Chiron that enmeshes him in silence, against the grain of the slim moments of inexplicable kindness that break through to nurture him towards trust.
public: hird act was a bore in my opinion - I'm not a fan of giving such huge emphasis on race and identity in movies (people should be portrayed as who they are as naturally as possible, or else it gives rise to stereotypes and outdated movie tropes) - the deliberate partitioning of the three acts made me want more out of the story. I love coming-of-age films, but leaving out the transitions between adolescence -> teen and teen -> adulthood was a little disappointing to me. And the sections can give us room for imagination, but the pacing made it hard for me to keep my interest in Chiron's development.

critic: Moonlight managed to beautify an area considered horrifically ugly and scarred. The movie also brilliantly tackled black masculinity, crack addiction and bullying with an honest and fresh approach.
public: Unbelievable. Nicely filmed, but ponderous, slow, not particularly well-acted (although it brought 'sulking' to a new level), I wanted to like the film, but it just went nowhere. While I can understand others enjoying it more than I, THIS is the film that won won Best Film of the Year? Huh? Unbelievable.....

critic: Moonlight is one of those films that play out like a huge build up towards an emotionally taut final act. Some will find the climax too understated but that's exactly what makes it feel real and powerful, just like the rest of the story.
public: This movie is incredibly beautiful and emotionally honest. A great deal has already been said about its impactful and telling portrayal of masculinity and emotional vulnerability, and how incredibly important this movie is. The actors were all stellar and felt very true to their characters, and the progression of the film was completely satisfying. This film makes you feel something deep within your chest, pain and joy, and underneath it all hope, that is rare and special in art. For any person who grew up as a child vulnerable and isolated, lonely and struggling, this will feel like an honest reflection on pain and hope

critic: The only way to describe Moonlight is as art. It's pure, unadulterated art. It's storytelling at it's best. It's filmmaking at it's best. It's romantic, emotional, and, most importantly, a film that needs to be seen.
public: I am probably the only one who actually didn't enjoy watching the movie. Mahershala Ali is the only good thing in this movie. Usually when we are watching a movie we expect a slow start and then much more emotion, a climax after a few minutes. Moonlight takes you through a good start to a boring ending. They killed Ali character after 30 minutes of movie and then you have to watch one hour slow dialogues.

critic: It will forever live as one of the most profoundly touching and mesmerizing films with a fantastic, diverse cast that demonstrated the power of intersectionality.
public: I admired the filmmaking, but didn't really connect with it. I thought some parts were very slow, especially the scene in the restaurant near the end. I didn't think the third section was as effective as the first two. The child actors are all really good, and I think anyone who has experienced bullying at school can relate to what Chiron goes through. It's not an easy watch and wasn't really for me, but I can see why some people love it.

critic: The film doesn't possess one of those purposefully frustrating indie movie endings where the credits roll the moment the filmmakers ran out of ideas. Moonlight finishes not on a period or an exclamation point, but an ellipsis.
public: The amount of work and thought that went into each and every frame is insane. This film is extremely meaningful and a beautiful story overall. It is not your typical "Hood" movie. The sound design matches the story in a oddly good way, that no movie has ever done before. Only downside of this film is it gets a teeny bit slow toward the end.

It's a well shot movie that partly feels like it was too obviously written for the critics. If you break the story down to the essential, you'll find too many "play-it-by-the-book sentimental drama" clichés and hardly anything surprising or new.

Taking a look at a coming-of-age story that is as special as it is powerful, Moonlight exquisitely represents two underlooked communities with authenticity and impeccable work from every single person involved. Incredible performances and an outstanding score are two of the things that make this even more emotionally impactful, while it also is visually beautiful, its raw and heartwarming depictions, such as love and types of abuse, are what make this film captivating and shocking, giving audiences a very bittersweet experience that sometimes may not be for the faint of heart, but that it eventually rewards with a heartfelt story.

The two time jumps in Moonlight are significantly difficult to overcome; especially the latter. Once Barry Jenkins finally gets you hooked on of the three stages of Chiron, he jumps to the next and just like that all traces of the last age flash are completely erased. Now with this said, Moonlight is still a decent movie, mainly because of Chiron's second age flash. I also would've enjoyed Moonlight much more if at least they would've made Chiron's third age flash slightly entertaining. I was bored out of my mind watching Chiron's third age flash and kept waiting for something significant to happen, but at the end of Moonlight I was left with a bland, boring taste

This was one of the most beautifully photographed, superbly set, and genuinely authentic films I've ever seen. Jenkins established a time and place perfectly, and told such an achingly honest and unsparing story of identity and self-awakening, it's almost like poetry. The use of a steadicam instead of a handheld gave it an uncommon grace and dignity which added to its authenticity. This is a movie I won't soon forget.

Beautiful coming of age story about vulnerability and the intersectionality of race, sexuality, economic status and age. Great representation on life. Plus the cinematography was perfect. Only downside was it was a little slow.

Wouldn’t this be far more moving and real if the kid grew up to be average looking, maybe with weight issues, etc....? But no... the gay black kid has to grow up to be a muscular black stud, and the camera fetishizing him with lingering shots over his torso

This is not a very different kind of hood movie. It focuses on the tough upbringing of a boy in the streets of Miami, rather than a lot of street violence and drugs. There isn't actually as much going on as you would expect. And some moments are long. But Moonlight manages to also have some powerful moments, and the cast are all pretty good. It deals with themes such as homosexuality, Afro-American identity and social classes. Which is why it won the Academy Award for beat picture. It's a sometimes touching flick and overall a good and very smart movie. Recommended!!

This film tries to do too much, yet covers zero original ground. For those who measure the value of a project in diversity, this lacks it ENTIRELY, being set in Miami, yet does not have a single white or Hispanic cast member. The only white people I recall seeing in the whole film were two background actors eating at a diner. I do not recall a single Hispanic, even as background. IN MIAMI. That's a wash or a loss, folks. Incredibly, rated 98/90. That's rated better by critics than THE SHAWSHANK REDEMPTION. (91/98). The world has gone mad

A heavily Oscar crafted indie film that definitely isn't for everybody. But this is what you get with company A24. The performances are spectacular, the directing is sharp, and it knows exactly what it wants to be. If your looking for those elements along with a boring film with thin consistency, no story to tell, weak writing, and characters that are difficult to relate to. Even for the LGBTs, than this is the film for you. For everyone else, it is not really their cup of tea.

I've seen Moonlight four times and I feel that this is the best film of all time. Never has anything I've ever seen come close to Moonlight, Barry Jenkins is going to achieve legendary status as a director in the near future as he wrings beauty in every scene despite the bleakest of circumstances. The three act structure is beautiful as we see a vulnerable boy who can't be himself struggle to find himself in his bleak life in working class America. It's a film unlike any other and one of the most deserved best picture winners ever. This will and always will be my favourite film and I have a feeling I'm going to enjoy every single film Jenkins makes.

This is one of the more interesting Best Picture winners that I have ever seen, it's a story about underprivileged African-Americans that is not seen through a white lens. There is no black and white in this film, those who treat the main character with love and care are complicit in the abuse of others and that makes a very complex film. Having recently seen If Beale Street Could Talk (2018) it was rewarding to look back at Barry Jenkins' breakout film and see all of the flourishes that make him such a unique director. Thank goodness that this and not the cringe worthy and forgettable La La Land (2016). We see a man Chiron,, at three different stages in his life as he progresses from troubled child with an abusive mother to confused homosexual teenager to emotionally neutered adult. The figures surrounding him who most matter are his drug-addicted mother, Naomie Harris, his childhood mentor, Mahershala Ali, and his high school friend,,. His mentor tries to teach him how to live a moral life but Chiron ends up following in his footsteps and becoming a drug dealer himself whilst his friend gives him a hand job on the beach but later beats him up after facing peer pressure. All of the abuse he has faced in his life lead to him becoming a man who directs all of his energy into exercise and the illegal activities that help him earn a living whilst having no outlet for his sexual frustration. What makes the film special is that these people are seen as just that normal people, not slaves or slightly simple but innocent folks who need to be helped along by an intellectually superior white person. Chiron faces many difficulties in his life a lot of which are probably influenced by racial inequality in the United States but racism is not the focus of the story instead we see his troubled coming of age in a black community in which complex figures exist. Teresa, Janelle Monae, is a kind, motherly figure that Chiron can look up to instead of his own abusive, troubled mother. We see two very different women, both black, with major supporting roles who both have significant flaws whilst also having redemptive moments. This sort of nuance is not present in The Help (2011) or The Blind Side (2009) in which African-Americans are reduced to supporting players who need the help of Emma Stone or Sandra Bullock. The presence of an extremely quiet, self-contained lead character could have made the film difficult to engage with but fortunately all three actors who portrayed the main character were very good at conveying internal strife. In particular,, was able to capture his character's ambivalence about his sexual attraction to his best friend. The actors manage to make their version of the character feel like a natural progression instead of feeling like a completely different interpretation this means that emotional moments have more impact as we have sympathy for that little boy on the beach when we understand that Chiron has become as bad as his mentor. If I had any criticism of the film, I have very little, I would say it's a fairly ugly film and I understand that the location that Chiron lives in is either rough or just dull but I still believe that more effort could be put in to add something to visual style of this film. In Knight of Cups (2015), a very different film I know, Christian Bale or Rick, as his character is known, visits Skid Row one of the roughest neighborhoods in the United States and yet through the lens of Emmanuel Lubezki there is a strange beauty to it. Lubezki is one of the best cinematographers working today and not every film is going to look as beautiful as something directed by Terrence Malick but you would still hope for something approaching grotesque beauty. This was definitely a deserving Best Picture winner as it was much better than any of the other films nominated that year but I personally preferred Manchester by the Sea (2016). Kudos to the Academy for rewarding a non-white savior narrative film about people of color, it's about damn time, but it's rather disappointing to see them regress with Green Book (2018).

As a guy who didn't like Boyhood, I feel like Moonlight, another film about a boy growing up, was infinitely better. Boyhood explored every single detail about Mason's life, and many of those details don't translate well as a narrative. Many plot points would be quickly forgotten and were never referenced again. Moonlight only shows three parts of Chiron's life, but those three parts are the most vital to the plot. This creates a narrative that is very engaging. Another thing I didn't like about Boyhood was that it shoved in a bunch of pop-culture references that were really dated by the time the film hit theaters. Moonlight never quite specifies when it takes place, making the film feel more timeless as the years go by. I know a lot of people really loved Boyhood, but I personally think Moonlight was a much better film on just about every level. The characters are more interesting, the story is very interesting, the editing is beyond genius, and overall, I feel that Moonlight will hold up in the years to come.

Personally I thought Harris was amazing in her role as a mother addicted to crack. Just flawless. Even the first and second Chiron's were great, but of course it is Jenkins who is the master at hand, creating a movie that had this calming quality to it yet is emotionally filled to the brim. That is truly something amazing. Too bad that this then ended on an utterly boring third act which moved so slowly. Did not like that at all.

Don't get me wrong it's a good film as you can see by my score but there are many other films that I remember much better in 2016 and this is the case for many films. The film is a coming of age story for a troubled youth in a violent atmosphere and his journey to be a person of character rather than a person that assimilates the nature of his environment. The most memorable performance without a doubt is Mahershala Ali who plays a father figure with his own ugly tendencies. I don't know if I would recommend Moonlight as it is a good film, but not a great one. It has great drama, but that is expected from a story like this. Still I would suggest that there are many other films to see that you will remember years later.

If this half ass movie can win best picture than I don't know what will in the future. Anyway the only good thing about this movie other than mahershala Ali's performance was the first act, the score was beautiful and the acting was excellent but it was really boring with a weak story. So in other words it sucked.

Moonlight is a modern masterpiece. The story may seem simple and familiar, but it is told in an extremely powerful way, addressing themes like masculinity, identity, love, race, class, and parenting, all told in a visceral way that makes the setting come to life through the eyes of the highly relatable outsider. I have no complaints about this film as I still can't get it out of my head. There is and has never been anything like Moonlight.

title: La La Land
critic: It's the careful balance between the emotional realism of the acting and the sheer technical audacity of the musical numbers that elevates the movie into the realm of greatness even before Chazelle rips out your heart with the extended, bittersweet coda.
public: Told with an affectionate spin consisting of masterfully vibrant images, La La Land may drag its feet admittedly more than it needs to but quickly corrects most errors with a speechlessly emotional ending.

critic: La La Land wants you to take in its beauty and get to know its young dreamers. The ending packs an emotional punch but most of the ride is a joyous visual feast that just wants you to have a good time.
public: One of the most memorable films of the decade. The casual transitions into mello numbers are a great throwback to an older era. People expecting an all out lungs/dance piece reflecting modern musicals often miss this. The style is supposed to be less committal. Thematically Chazelle's message and vision is also super coherent and he really sticks the melancholy sweet landing.

critic: While the movie is "tongue in cheek" and may not completely live up to the movie musical grandeur of olden days, it is, nonetheless, an uplifting, fun film.
public: La La Land is a movie that affected me deeply from start to finish. Vibrant colors, beautiful songs, excellent acting, fantastic cinematography, and top-notch acting are aplenty in this film. The first time I viewed La La Land it took my breath away, and I don't mean that metaphorically, I literally did not think to breath for at least 10 seconds. I felt that the world had paused, it hit me hard with the brilliant ending sequence. I've since seen La La Land 3 more times and each time it still affects me emotionally, Damien Chazelle has done it again. I had no idea he directed this and Whiplash when I had first seen this, but I was a huge fan of Whiplash as another movie that affected me emotionally. La La Land is a masterpiece and has solidified itself as my favorite movie of all-time. It is beautiful in every capacity, vibrant and boisterous as much as it is melancholy. Thank you Damien for creating this movie.

critic: The director replaces the dances with a sense of rhythm, applying musical mathematics with precision to the cinematographic narrative, its images, the dialogues, carry a hidden musical compass.
public: STUPID, BORING, WORST MOVIE OF THE DECADE, WORSE THAN CATS.

critic: A shameless love letter to a bygone era of cinema, but it leverages that nostalgia to hide a tragic lesson about life and love.
public: This film will captivate you from the opening sequence, which I dare say is maybe the best musical introduction since Chicago back in 2002. Gosling and Stone are charming and the cinematography of Sandgren coupled with a flawless direction from Damian Chazelle helped us care for both characters. It will however all be in vain if not for the sublime Justin Hurwitz who created one of the best scores of the decade. Mia and Sebastian theme in particular was so catchy and beautiful, and of course the Oscar winning song "city of stars" I'm sure many people will have some other better opinion of jazz music after this due to the simplicity of its melodies. The film will manage to take you slowly but surely to the realistic epilogue that will probably slap you so hard that you will keep on gazing at the screen long after the credits roll.

critic: To love La La Land is to do the work for the film it didn't do itself. It requires sanitizing Sebastian, and to a lesser degree Mia, and endowing them with characteristics they never demonstrate.
public: I don't get it. People think Ryan Gosling is dreamy, and that's okay. I don't really like musicals, so I'm not the best judge, but I feel like the singers should be able to sing. Don't get the hype on this one.

critic: A ravishing romance, to be sure, filled with romance deliriously exhilarating music and declarations of love in the classic Hollywood vein.

critic: The takeaway for me is the love story here. At risk of understatement, this is a cinematic love story for the ages. This is a story we haven't seen on screen before, at least certainly not done this well.
public: Damien Chazelle and company out did themselves with this nod to one of the best eras in cinema. The duo of Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling were even more electric than they are in real life. With Damien's extensive knowledge of such classics as Singin' in the Rain, Broadway Melody of 1940 and Sweet Charity, La La Land shines with a brilliant mixture of comebacks and new material. With 5 Oscar wins, I feel like the film was short changed and should have won at least 8, including Best Picture. If La La Land is not one of the best movies in history, it certainly is one of the best since the turn of the century.

critic: La La Land shows us a Hollywood fable of failure and desperation dressed up with a fresh coat of new-wave earnestness and nostalgia.
public: So a beautiful movie. The cinematography, the colours, the dancing and of corse the music make this such a brilliant movie. The final scene is definitely sad and the 30 seconds of silence with the characters looking at each other from across the bar is such a great moment as it seems the characters have a full conversation without saying a word to each other. really wanted to love this film since I have been a serious fan of Hollywood musicals since I was a small child. However, I came away feeling that the sole reason to see this film is to bask in the amazing shots - it is truly a beautiful film. Lighting, staging, color and photography are all top notch, and sometimes transcendent. There is a regularly displayed love of the dolly shot through the film (though in today's tech-wizard film,making, I kept wondering if the oft-used fast-pan was a digital way of cutting between takes, or if it was an actual pan). Disappointingly, everything else gets in the way of the beauty that this film displays. I was surprised that awards were given out for the acting, as it seemed as lacking in depth as the painfully hackneyed plot. I couldn't sympathize with either character as they were both insufferable with no redeeming traits other than their attractiveness (which, to be fair, is commonly the case with struggling LA actors and musicians - but this isn't supposed to be a gritty reality film). I actively wanted their relationship to fail and I usually like silly romantic films (my fave film in the romantic genre is Somewhere in Time). This is a musical, but musicals require BIG songs that you keep humming as you leave the theater and that you want to hear again (think The Music Man, Oliver, West Side Story, Mary Poppins). However, the music in this film was either un-hummable jazz (yes, I do like jazz) or insipid, forgettable songs that I wanted to be over as fast as possible. The vocalists were adequate singers in a bland current-pop sort of way, but that's not how its done in musicals. They're working in a medium that gave us Garland, Minelli, Streisand, Kelly, Preston...these poor La La actors just don't rate. But, oh - those visuals. They are so good that I kept watching to see what was next. So go to school on the photography and if you get into films because the actors are good to look at, you'll be extra happy.Just don't expect substance or the genuine feel of a Hollywood musical.

This is the sort of film that makes you detest musicals with how simultaneously twee and self important it is and the fact that the two leads can barely dance and sing. Damien Chazelle directed the very good Whiplash (2014) which explores the pressures of being an artist with dramatic flair but the other two films that he has directed that I have seen have been huge disappointments. This film was frustrating with it's nods to old Hollywood that felt perfunctory instead of feeling like a genuine tribute and it had the sort of half baked qualities that a film like The Artist (2011) possesses. This is not something that anybody should be clamoring to see and it is offensive to the brilliant Moonlight (2016) that this would ever be considered worthy competition to it. Aspiring actress Mia, Emma Stone, tentatively begins a relationship with classical jazz aficionado Sebastian, Ryan Gosling, after they bond at a friend's party. Mia decides to write and perform in a one woman play to jump start her acting career and Sebastian joins a modern jazz band led by Keith, John Legend, who he rebels against as their musical tastes are opposed to his own. Their relationship begins to break down as their ambitions are completely different and their relationship would require a lot of commitment in order to last. They each attain career success but do not end up together and reminisce about the life they could have had when they see each other again years later. From the opening scene of the film in which people in brightly colored clothing jump out of their cars, stuck in a traffic jam, to perform the lackluster song "Another Day of Sun" to jerky choreography I knew I hated this film. From this point the film only gets worse as the songs blend together and Stone's monotonous delivery of her lines leaves us rudderless without a charismatic leading lady. I was hoping throughout for some redemptive moment, something that I could pick out and argue in favor of the film for but I was left with nothing. Going into the film I knew that I was particularly tough on musicals, I can only name a few that I actually like, and I detest Stone as an actress but if I can love One from the Heart (1982) and The Favorite (2018) I thought I could tolerate these two elements to find a great film lurking underneath. The success of a musical to me rests on the quality of the song and dance numbers and this film lacks any memorable tunes and the choreography is limited as the two lead actors can't dance. Even An American in Paris (1951), which is mostly Leslie Caron being awful and dull conversation, partially rescues itself with a magnificent final scene but the closest this film got to competence was using a cover of A-ha's "Take on Me" over the party scene. Gosling simply can't sing as he drawls all of the lines in his big song, "City of Stars", and Stone is unconvincing as a dancer or a singer which ruins the film considering the fact that she is lumped with most of the workload. The scene of the two of them dancing on the ceiling of the Griffith Conservatory could have been something beautiful but it is ruined by the scenes before and after it and only really works when divorced from the dislikable characters. Stone's win for Best Actress is blasphemous as she beat out the far superior Isabelle Huppert in Elle (2016) and will now shamefully be placed in the same category as Jessica Lange and Elizabeth Taylor as an actress undeserving of an Academy Award. Gosling doesn't fare much better although he can give great dramatic performances and Legend's role, essentially a cameo, suits him well. This is the dream! It's conflict and it's compromise, and it's very, very exciting!" Where to start? I'll be honest, based on the trailers that I saw I wasn't very excited to see this; I thought that it would just be average or slightly above and incredibly artsy either way. Let me say, I love being proved wrong when it comes to a film being better than I thought it would be, and I was proven very wrong in this case. In my opinion, this is what film making is about. Director Damien Chazelle came out of the gates swinging in 2014 with Whiplash (probably one of my top ten films of all time). He hits the ball out of the park this time by telling the story of Sebastian (Ryan Gosling) a jazz pianist and Mia (Emma Stone) an aspiring actress who bump into one another on more than a few occasions resulting in a roller coaster of emotions. I know that musicals (especially modern day ones) are often looked upon in a certain light by most. Sure there is singing and even several incredible dance numbers in La La Land, yet beyond all of that it has so much more to offer. The story isn't the best ever told but the way it is captured both visually and through the song and dance is almost beyond words. Both Gosling and Stone have achieved what I'd consider their best performances in their careers to this point. Please don't go into this expecting Singin' in the Rain, The Sound of Music or even Grease. This film transcends the traditional role of a musical to offer something that I've not seen before. Damien Chazelle's idea was to "to take the old musical but ground it in real life where things don't always exactly work out." He more than succeeded in his vision by crafting a great movie into a fantastic musical. Too often, musicals have strained performances and misplaced song and dance numbers. La La Land has masterful performances with song and dance seamlessly incorporated to enhance the story even further. Most musicals deliver several great songs; however, this film with John Legend as a producer, delivers incredible songs that have already won awards. "City of Stars," sung by Gosling himself, was a bright point in a film that already had so many. Honestly, before watching this I had no clue that Gosling or Stone could sing. While neither are likely to go on to have exciting musical careers, they both stretched their talents and sung to the level of their characters with perfection. One of the few things that I take for granted in film are the captivating visuals. I've seen so many major blockbuster sci-fi adventures that I rarely stop to appreciate the subtlety that a true artist can bring to the screen. Everything from matte paintings, lighting, and cinematography play a role in giving a film a look and feel that take you to another world. The visuals in La La Land are truly a work of art, the colors jump off the screen, and thanks to the lighting throughout, your eyes are directed exactly where they're meant to be. On top of Damien's incredible directorial style, he also wrote both Whiplash and La La Land. Chazelle is a true artist that I'm looking forward to seeing more and more from in the coming years. title: HACKSAW RIDGE
critic: A rousing tale of Pacific War heroism that has more in common with jingoistic Wayne staples such as Sands of Iwo Jima or The Green Berets than anything in the 21st century, this is wearily formulaic film-making.
public: Somewhat torn about this. The directing, look and acting is top-notch, no doubt about it. Especially the huge battle scenes are impressive, disgusting and engaging, almost rivaling Saving Private Ryan's. The beginning does take its time introducing our protagonist and his early life. public: rom Mel Gibson comes the World War II drama Hacksaw Ridge. Based on a true story the film follows conscientious objector Desmond Doss as he fights to be allowed to serve as an Army Medic and ends up playing a pivotal role in the Battle of Okinawa. Starring Andrew Garfield, Hugo Weaving, Sam Worthington, Teresa Palmer, and Vince Vaughn, the film has an impressive cast that delivers some strong performances. And as usual, Gibson does an incredible job at showing the gritty reality of war. The writing is also especially good; exploring such themes as adhering to one's religious convictions and the personal toll that violence takes. An extraordinarily compelling story about faith and heroism, Hacksaw Ridge is a powerful film.

critic: Gibson has made a movie that's nearly pathological in its love of violence-but he nonetheless counterbalances its amoral pleasures with an understanding of the psychological devastation that war wreaks.
public: Charging forth with a pacifist war story that's anything but passive, director Mel Gibson channels the vicious punch and visceral panache of some vaulted war films from H'Wood's past in telling the story of one very Brave Heart who's Passion for the Christ found him sticking to his religious, er, guns during one of World War II's deadliest skirmishes. In this R-rated war movie, pacifist WWII American Army Medic Desmond T. Doss (Andrew Garfield) refuses to kill people during the Battle of Okinawa and becomes the first man in American history to receive the Medal of Honor without firing a shot. Sporting a hard R rating, the film unapologetically pains a very bloody picture. Ironically and unsurprisingly skewing more toward the War is Hell mantra (made famous as the memoir title of another unlikely WWII underdog hero, Audie Murphy) than, say, one that proselytizes Peace is Heaven, this film's title says everything about its tone: Hacksaw Ridge. The ironic part arises from the fact that it's a story about pacifist convictions. The unsurprising part stems from the fact that it comes courtesy of a man made iconic by ultra-violent actioner Lethal Weapon, an artist who (kinda, sorta) also made 'historic' filmic violence iconic with Braveheart. To this end, there's two reasons why it wasn't titled The Desmond Doss Story. Due to the extreme but strategic use of violence, he film proves both a thoughtful rumination on the duality of man that's as much a statement by Gibson as Doss. For better and worse, Gibson zeroes in on two flicks for inspiration: Full Metal Jacket and Saving Private Ryan (All Quiet on the Western Front doubtlessly is another but many will miss the connection given that, at 87 years old, that film as a cultural touchstone has timed out for anybody but film historians). The better? Hacksaw Ridge comes way closer than most to equaling the gut punch realism of these modern war classics, serving up a demoralizing boot camp segment that would make Jacket's R. Lee Emery's Drill Sgt. proud (Vince Vaughn, in a surprising but rewarding casting choice, believably doles out the vitriol) and setting the second half in an embattled Pacific warzone (amphibious landing, body count, jettisoned limbs, and all) that sometimes looks like Ryan Normandy Beach scenes picked up from the cutting room floor. The worse? The telltale stylistic beats 'borrowed' from these films can't be missed. Still, if Gibson hadn't already earned a place as a vaunted director with Braveheart and The Passion of the Christ, Hacksaw Ridge almost ensures him entry. The most expensive independent movie of all time (in his heyday, Gibson could get a Mother Theresa snuff film financed with one phone call but, post 2010 public meltdown amid a fickle film industry, he had to piece together financiers like a Shark Tank contestant) delivers a remarkable and well-shot true story. Sticking to your guns - even when sticking to your guns specifically involves sticking to no guns - becomes more than a religious argument. It sets fire to a contentious conversation about a public trying to peacefully go about their day despite mass shootings being an almost weekly occurrence. Destined for Direct-to-Video status after The Amazing Spider-Man series toppled into oblivion, Andrew Garfield gives a layered and nuanced performance. It's not enough that he believably embodies the belief system of Desmond Doss's pacifist, he also looks and acts every bit like the simple - though not simpleton - farmer. As he's proven with Apocalypto and every film he's directed involving armed conflict (and, saved for Man Without a Face, they all do), Gibson puts forth a contemplative message saying peace is better than war but, ultimately, violence as an ends-to-a-means is often unavoidable ...or so it seems. Perhaps, the title of Lethal Weapon was simply hailing the coming of a cinematic realist. To Sum it Up: Soldier of Good Fortune

critic: The battle scenes in "Hacksaw Ridge" are among the most violent captured on film - and also the most urgent.
public: ne cannot deny that Mel Gibson can direct the hell out of a battle sequence but in this film the sequences would seem to go against the ideology of the subject and there is a horror in having the director openly delight in gruesome violence. Additionally the film is very much of two halves and unfortunately the first feels like a laughable parody version of The Best Years of Our Lives (1946) with how cheesy it is and the second half is entirely discordant with this opening. Many acclaimed the film as Gibson's comeback to mainstream Hollywood productions but I have little appreciation for the film beyond Gibson's technical abilities and I wish that it had a stronger screenplay and was less indulgent in graphic violence. As a child in Virginia in the 1920s Desmond Doss, Andrew Garfield, almost kills his brother with a brick and is driven to adopt strict Seventh Day Adventist beliefs and is a conscientious objector when World War II begins. He chooses to enlist despite a romance with nurse Dorothy Schutte, Teresa Palmer, but is confronted by the aggressive Sergeant Howell, Vince Vaughn, when he refuses to learn how to use a weapon. He is almost convicted for his actions but when his superiors learn of new laws he is allowed to become a medic without using a gun. He is seen as a coward by his fellow soldiers but proves his heroism during a battle at Hacksaw Ridge during the Battle of Okinawa. He saves 75 men by helping them to escape down a ridge and men who had previously dismissed him are astonished by his bravery and conduct. He returns to civilian life after the war, marries Schutte and does not become boastful about his achievements by choosing instead to thank god. Before I discuss the second half of the film, where Gibson's interest really lies, I must discuss the first half which felt more like a television soap opera than Since You Went Away (1944) or whatever 1940s classic he was attempting to evoke. Doss is clearly meant to come as naïve but good hearted in his young adulthood but he seems to have some sort of mental issue as he awkwardly pursues the improbably beautiful nurse. The dialogue in their first date scene was atrocious and Schutte's constant smiles and gentle teasing made her seem like the sort of ‘ideal' woman that housewives in the 1950s were pushed to act like. When he kisses her in a supposedly spontaneous moment it was totally manufactured and the moment in which Schutte pushes her religious boyfriend to marry her was so cliché that it could have come out of a parody of this sort of film. The parallels with Michael Bay's Pearl Harbor (2001) were uncomfortable and much like that film you feel as bored as the director does waiting for the macho action to begin. There is an equally awkward sequence before our men enter the battlefield that tries to get us invested in the ‘zany' soldiers that Doss will be fighting alongside. We open with a surprisingly long shot of a man's buttocks and then hear a group of Australian actors introduce themselves in thick ‘Brooklyn' accents. This does little to make us care and there are so many films that these scenes are reminiscent of, from Full Metal Jacket (1987) to From Here to Eternity (1953), that it is hard to view them on their own. Then he introduces the arbitrary drama of having him court martialed and then ends this part of the film on a dull note as his superiors are informed of a fact that they should have already known. When Doss finally finds himself on the battlefield you can sense that Gibson has relaxed as he does choreograph stunning scenes of gore and violence that inform the audience of the horror of fighting in a war. However beyond all of the explosions and close up shots of blood leaking out of men's severed legs there is the uncomfortable feeling that Gibson is enjoying all of this a little too much and unlike his pacifist hero completely endorses violence. The film definitely deserved to be honored for the technical achievements that it made but as a whole it is a disappointment as the points it tries to make about pacifism are buried under Gibson's passion for violence and the dialogue is too hokey to be taken seriously.

Strengths: I chose to watch this movie because it was nominated for Best Picture a few years back. I see why. The story is Oscar bait, telling a courageous true story. Mel Gibson nailed his work as a director here. He handles the first half of the film solidly, giving us plenty of strong character moments. It's the second half where he truly shines, though. The war sequences are brutal and tense. Body parts fly around, there are abrupt deaths, and you feel like you're right there watching the action in person. It makes sense that this was also nominated for editing and sound mixing. The experience on the battlefield is something truly special. Andrew Garfield (Desmond Doss) gives one of the best performances of his career, other than the bad accent. The rest of the cast like Hugo Weaving (Tom Doss), Sam Worthington (Jack Glover), and the surprisingly strong Vince Vaughn (Sgt. Howell) all bring their best. Weaknesses: The movie feels long. You completely feel every single minute because some parts do drag in the early stages. Teresa Palmer (Dorothy Schutte) is the one actor who doesn't feel like they're doing a great job. She's not flat out bad, but she lacks something. Her chemistry with Andrew Garfield is almost non-existent, so the love story plot never really works. Overall: This blew me away and was way better than I expected. Other than some pacing issues and the love story, everything works. We have strong characters, a good script, great direction, and the feel like we're truly watching the brutal nature of war.

The redeeming factor is the second half. Mel Gibson simply creates these amazingly brutal, realistic battle sequences that hold nothing back. The very first death is shocking in its bloodiness and its abruptness, having a survivor of the previous siege become reanimated, giving away the position of the battalion. Once this has happened, we see his head blown off, followed immediately by the death of the man who disturbed him being dealt a similar fate. The following sequence showcases just how brutal war can be, displaying death as being as normal as breathing. This film being based on a true story adds a sense of amazement as you realize not only is this plausible, but it is also what happened. Watching a man, carrying little more then a giant first aid kit, save 75 men who had been injured during 2 days of fighting upon the titular ridge and roping them down the massive expanse at the detriment of his hands. Andrew Garfield, horrible accent aside, plays this role very well, especially as we get more into the war time scenes and the training sequences. This film was nominated for 6 Oscars, winning for film editing and sound mixing, two things that truly mesmerized me during this film. My only complaint is that we did not get a pay off of the brother going to war first nor do we get any insight into the motivations of the father as he helps his son get into the army and also hearing what he has done in Okinawa. This movie is not for the faint of heart, the depictions of war, fighting and death are very realistic and can be offensive or nauseating to those that are not ready for it. Watch at your own discretion.

Over-the-top and excessive in every aspect (some might say indulgent, but others seem to love over-dramatized films like this), from the stereotypic love story to the unrelenting battle scenes. Mel Gibson directed and having not seen any other films by him, I can only suspect that the mix of hard-core religion and ultra-violence is his own personal signature. Andrew Garfield plays Desmond Doss, a conscientious objector who nevertheless signs up for combat duty in WWII (in the Pacific theatre) to serve as a medic. He gets hard done by during boot camp, pilloried for his religious beliefs and nearly court-martialled and drummed out of the service for refusing to carry a weapon. But, of course, he prevails and ends up with the medal of honour. The true story upon which the film is based is undoubtedly moving and inspiring but the syrupy ode to the man is pretty tough to take at times. The centrepiece of the film is more than an hour of gory battle scenes, with corpses everywhere, men dying in horrific fashion, and a genuine hell-on-earth mise-en-scene. Perhaps this is how battle really feels - but do you really need to see it? I'm sure the technical wizardry required is impressive but again, the sweeping music and dramatic crescendos nearly capsize things. A bunch of Australians take roles here (alongside an always charismatic Vince Vaughan) but few are able to define their characters above the fray. Watch if you must but there are better war films (e.g., The Steel Helmet, 1951 or The Big Red One, 1980, both by Sam Fuller).

The Jew-hatting director is back and it hurts to admit it's good! I've heard some people say that they couldn't see a Woody Allen because "he's a perv" and some saying the same for Tarantino because he can be too loud (for me, he's the man!). I've never been one of this people but I do believe we have to take into consideration a filmmaker's life to understand his work. Thus, my perception of The 400 Blows wouldn't be the same without me knowing about Truffaut's childhood or Edward Scissorhands would be less impactful had I not known of Burton's inner struggles growing up. I truly believe that Mel Gibson is a despicable person and not that great of an actor... But, he's a talented director! Firstly, the film is based on a great true story that everyone should learn about which is a great structure to the fine script. Garfield is powerful and believable in the character, Hugo Weaving is menacing and, surprisingly, Vince Vaughn is a pertinent casting decision. What may stand out the most about this film is how Gibson constructs a battle scene. He does it without mercy, showing us the true nature of war, all the blood and guts splattering all over, the big explosions and the courage in the soldier's eyes. This, which is supported by thoughtful editing, rugged cinematography and convincing makeup/ SFX work makes up for an immersive experience that is both engrossing and hard to look away from. It's war in it's purest form, like I haven't seen for a while. The problem is precisely when the director's personality surfaces and lets his over-nationalistic pride take over the whole picture. In this day and age, I do think that we shouldn't portray enemies, villains, etc in any kind of movie as generic, as nothing more than evil. This dehumanization of the antagonist is all too problematic in this film, as the Japanese seem to serve the only purpose of being blown up. Furthermore, the stereotypically southern way characters interact, how they create friendships, how they fall in love makes it hard for me to relate to them. Still, the film hit me hard at the end when footage of the real Desmond Doss was shown and I no longer could fight the tears. It's like Gibson was able to pass on to me the ominous patriotic feel and give me a taste of what war actually feels like, which is no easy feat.

public: In my mind's eye, "Manchester By The Sea" deserves its praise at the arthouse and filmmaking levels, as it is a poignant examination of human grief that is hard to touch. But perhaps like few other films in history have, it also epitomizes the rancorous gap between the erudite grading scale of Academy Awards voters, and the public's desire to see their most joyously-consumed films be deemed worthy of cinema's highest accolades. It's likely the true fire starter film to the Academy's proposed inclusion of an "Outstanding Achievement in Popular Film" award. I personally found Casey Affleck to be very solid but short of mesmerizing as a janitor forced to care for his deceased brother's boy. I enjoyed the film itself far more than the collective acting. But regardless of the nits and gnats, The Academy's recent consideration to recognize blockbusters -- while largely frowned upon by alarmist film snobs -- is perhaps it's the best conciliatory olive branch available, allowing fine films like "Manchester By The Sea" to earn its deserved recognition, yet not without an equalizing tip of the cap to public sentiment. This is a very good movie that falls short of an eternal masterpiece, and perhaps might be best remembered long-term by its contribution to a larger public debate between the need to champion great storytelling while also allowing the voices of the masses to also be heard.

This film affected me deeply. It was one of the best and most astute depictions of grief I've seen in a long time, heartwrenching and beautifully told. This is the sort of film that you have to watch in the right mood, if you don't want to be left broken and in tears or just plain angry. I came to the film as a fan of Kenneth Lonergan, his two previous films are among the best of the 21st century, so I was expecting dark and depressing material and a very flawed main character. The other expectation I had coming into the film was that it would contain great acting and this proved to be true as Casey Affleck and Lucas Hedges give beautiful performances. This is a film that deserves to be savored and it is filled with incredibly emotional moments that are painful to watch but have the sort of realism that clings to all of Lonergan's productions. Lee Chandler, Casey Affleck, is a depressed janitor working in Quincy, Massachusetts who is called back to his hometown of Manchester by the Sea after the death of his brother Joe, Kyle Chandler. In his will Joe outlines that he wants Lee to become the legal guardian of his son Patrick, Lucas Hedges, and remain in Manchester by the Sea. Patrick and Lee bond as they struggle after the death of a beloved family member and while Patrick juggles multiple girlfriends and Lee's past comes back to haunt him. His inability to change leaves you frustrated with him and yet he is sympathetic in his complete lack of desire to confront his dark past. Lonergan's screenplay, as with all of his screenplays, is very naturalistic in most of it's interactions with this being punctuated by moments of intense violence and emotional conflict where problems aren't necessarily dealt with. When Patrick awkwardly tries to connect with Lee he speaks like a real, immature teenager not like the precocious invention of a middle aged screenwriter. The actors deserve credit for their work in crafting these characters of course but they are given a tight, deliberate script to work with that forces them to act between the lines. The lack of dialogue that Lee receives conveys his utter hopelessness as Randi's monologue shows her own desperation and enduring love for her ex-husband, everything in the screenplay has been so well thought out that it's not surprising it won the Best Original Screenplay Academy Award. The best part of the film is undoubtedly the performance of Affleck as he exquisitely portrays a broken shell of a man. Although I won't reveal what he is lost we do understand in the film that Lee was once a happy and fulfilled but still significantly troubled man. The way that we see him throughout most of the film however is as a man who refuses to express emotion for fear of the pain of his past fully resurfacing. His reticence hurts those around him as his selfishness and anger is displayed by Affleck's soulless eyes and tightly pulled lips. He never makes his character sympathetic but if he were to even attempt that the film wouldn't work and his unmoved posturing throughout fits the character perfectly. The other standout performances, everyone in this film is great, are those of Michelle Williams and Lucas Hedges who each get moments to shine. Hedges get several arguments with Affleck to tear into and he manages to match him as their interplay with one another is spiky but loving, reminiscent of Sammy and Terry in You Can Count On Me (2000). His teenager is self-possessed, arrogant and very naÃ¯ve, in other words he is a normal teenager. Williams is incredible as she inhabits a character who may be even more traumatized than Lee and sells the pain that this woman would have held with her for years so well. I was awed by their abilities and completely believed in their characters and their motivations even when they made strange choices. This is a great exploration of several troubled people with dark pasts who try as they might can't find it in themselves to change. It leaves you as hollow as it's main character but that's the intent of the film, understanding grief should not be a pleasant experience. This is a film that should be watched if you are prepared for an intense emotional experience.
